publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
The Humble Petition of Frances Harris,
who must starve, and Dy a Maid if it Miscarries.
see page 258
Humbly sheweth.
That I went to warm my self in Lady Betty's Chamber, because I was Cold
And I had in a purse 7ḷ 8ṣ 4ḍ (beside Farthings) in Mony and Gold.
So because I had been buying Things for my Lady last Night
I was Resolv'd to tell my Mony to see if it was Right.
Now you must know because my Trunk has a uery Bad Lock
Therfore all the Mony I have which Alas, is a uery small Stock
I keep in a Pocket ty'd about my Middle next my Smock
So when I put up my purse as ill luck wou'd have it, my Shift was unripp'd
And instead of putting it into my Pocket down it slipt
Then the Bell rung and I went down to put my Lady to Bed
When I verily thought my Mony was as Safe as my Maiden-Head.
So when I came up agen, I found my Pocket very light
But when I search'd and Missed my Purse, I thought I shou'd ha' sunk outright.
Lord Madam says Mary, How Do you doe? Indeed says I neuer worse
But pray Mary Can you tell what I have Done with my Purse.
Lord help me said Mary I neuer stirr'd out of this Place.
Nay said I, I had it in Lady Betty's Chamber that's a Plain Case.So Mary gott me to Bed and Cover'd me up warm
Howeuer she stole away my Garters, That I might Do my self no Harm.
So I tumbl'd and toss'd all the Night, as you may very well think
But hardly euer set my Eies togather, or slept a wink.So I was Dream'd methoughts that we went and search'd ye folks round
And in a Corner of Mrs Duke's Box, ty'd in a Rag, the Mony was Found.So next Morning wee told Whittle, and He fell a Swearing;
Than Mrs Wadgar Comes, and She you must know is Thick of Hearing.
Dame said I as loud as I Cou'd Bawl, do yu know wt a loss I have had,
Nay, said she my Lḍ1Ld: Galloway.Colway's Folks are all uery Sad──
For my Lord 2Ld: Drogheda.Dromedary Comes a Tusday without Fail──Puh said I, but thats not the Business I ail.
Says Cary, says He, I have been a Servṭ this 5. an 20 years Come Spring
And in all the Places I liv'd, I neuer heard of such a Thing.
Yes, says the Steward when I was at my Lady Shrewsbury's
Such a Thing as this happen'd, just about the time of Goosburys.
So I went to the Party suspected, and found her full of greif.
Now you must know of all Things in the World, I hate a Theif.
However I was resolu'd to bring the Discourse Slily about
Mrs Duke's said I, here's an Vgly Accident happen'd out;
'Tis not that I value the Mony three Skips of a Lowse,
But the Thing I stand upon is the Credit of the Howse.
'Tis true 7ḷ an 4ṣ an 6ḍ makes a great Hole in my Wages
Besides as they say, service is no Inheritance in these Ages;
Now Mrs: Dukes you know and every Body Vnderstands
That tho' 'tis hard to judg──Mony Can't go without Hands.
The Devil take me said she (Blessing herself) if I euer saw't
So she roar'd like a Bedlam, as tho'f I had Call'd Her to Naught.
So, you know what cou'd I say to her any more
I e'en left her; and came away as wise as I was before.
Well; but then they wou'd have had me gone to the Cunning Man
No said I tis the same Thing, The Chaplain will be here anon.
So the Chaplain Came in, Now the Servants say, He is my Sweet-HeartBecause hee's alwaies in my Chamber, and I alwaies take his part.
So, as the Devil wou'd haue it, before I was aware, out I blunder'd
Parson said I, can you Cast a Nativity when a Body's Plunder'd.
Now you must know, He hates to be Call'd Parson like ye Devil;
Truly said he, Mrṣ Nab; it might become you to be more Civill.
If your Mony be gone; As a Learned Divine say's d'ye see
You are no Text for my handling, take that from mee.
I was neuer taken for a Conjuror before, I'd haue you to know
Lord said I, don't be Angry, I'm sure I never Thought you So.
You know I honour the Cloath; I design to be a Parsons Wife;
I neuer took one in your Coat, for a Conjurer in all my Life.
With that He Twisted his Girdle like a Rope, as who shou'd say
Now you may go Hang your self for me, and so went away.
Well, I thought I shou'd have Swoon'd, Lord said I, what shall I Do?
I've lost my Mony, and I shall loose my True-Love too.
Then my Lord Call'd me, Harris said my Lord, don't Cry
I'le give somthing toward thy loss, and says my Lady so will I.
Oh but said I, what if after all, my Chaplain won't come too
For that He said, (an't please your Excellencys) I must Petition you.
The Premisses tenderly Consider'd, I desire yr Excellencys Protection
And that I may haue a share in Next Sundays Collection.
And ouer and aboue, that I may haue your Excellencys Letter
With an Order for the Chaplain aforesaid, or (instead of Him) a Better.
And then your Poor Petitioner both Night and Day,
Or the Chaplain (for 'tis His Trade) as in Duty Bound shall euer pray.069-651B
